columns.text: in this problem, we will consider how interest rate swaps can benefit the two parties involved. Moreover, we will also recall the difference between a floating interest rate and a fixed interest rate.

**a.** When doing an interest rate swap, two entities exchange the interest rates of their fixed interest and floating interest so that they each entity can get better rates. Based on the given information, we can see that both companies can benefit with an interest swap since company ABC has a lower floating interest rate while company XYZ has a lower fixed interest rate. When they engage in an interest rate swap, company ABC will have a lower fixed interest rate that can offset the losses in their floating rate while company XYZ will have a lower floating rate that can offset their losses in the fixed rate.

**b.** The initial profit of the bank will if the terms are kept as is will be $3\%$. In order to allow both companies better gains and still net the bank a $2\%$ profit, we can use these terms:

Company ABC will borrow using their floating interest rate of LIBOR + $1\%$ and then swap their fixed interest rate as $10.5\%$ instead of $11\%$.

Company XYZ will borrow using their fixed interest rate of $10\%$ and then swap their floating rate of LIBOR + $2.5\%$ instead of LIBOR + $3\%$. 

Both companies can obtain loans using their lower interest rate, floating interest for ABC and fixed interest for XYZ, while at the same time, they will be paying using the other companies more favorable rate. 

These conditions will net both companies better terms while still giving the bank a $2\%$ profit.
